posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
One of my favorite things to do post FRC season is look around at what other teams did.  Last year it was cool to learn about some of the april tag mapping tools teams implemented.

So the question remains: What cool things did you do in Software this year?

(Or I guess, what cool features did you see in software this year, if it was something from another team!)

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
GTSAM: Beyond the standard 4 camera PV based apriltag detection system we’ve run for a few years now, this year we began using a factor-graph based system to generate pose estimates using GTSAM on our Nvidia Jetson Orin Nano Super Coprocessor.

GTSAM: Beyond the standard 4 camera PV based apriltag detection system we’ve run for a few years now, this year we began using a factor-graph based system to generate pose estimates using GTSAM on our Nvidia Jetson Orin Nano Super Coprocessor.

Depth Camera: We used a StereoLabs ZED 2i depth camera on our robot (with a fully CUDA accelerated back-end) for object detection, which allowed us to fully automate intakeing in ground during teleop by measuring the true 3d position of, and angle relative to our camera, for coral. This allowed us to make a “single click” automated pickup sequence that ensures we can pickup coral easily from any angle. With this we achieved nearly 60fps performance, even with a full FP32 model.

Depth Camera: We used a StereoLabs ZED 2i depth camera on our robot (with a fully CUDA accelerated back-end) for object detection, which allowed us to fully automate intakeing in ground during teleop by measuring the true 3d position of, and angle relative to our camera, for coral. This allowed us to make a “single click” automated pickup sequence that ensures we can pickup coral easily from any angle. With this we achieved nearly 60fps performance, even with a full FP32 model.

Heavy Teleop automation: We created automated scoring, climbing, and HP intake sequences which were able to dynamically navigate around obstacles. we also pretty much totally automated turning for our driver, with that automation behavior changing based on the game and robot state.

Heavy Teleop automation: We created automated scoring, climbing, and HP intake sequences which were able to dynamically navigate around obstacles. we also pretty much totally automated turning for our driver, with that automation behavior changing based on the game and robot state.

Custom Button Board: We build a custom button control board which allowed our operator to initiate scoring sequences for any reef position (from anywhere on the filed), control the climb, and automation override. Though this also came with the goal of giving our diver as much control as possible, so they still had access to “smart” scoring buttons on the back of their controller.

Custom Button Board: We build a custom button control board which allowed our operator to initiate scoring sequences for any reef position (from anywhere on the filed), control the climb, and automation override. Though this also came with the goal of giving our diver as much control as possible, so they still had access to “smart” scoring buttons on the back of their controller.

Honorable Mentions: LEDs that were actually surprisingly useful, massively overcomplicated superstructure motion logic, and a 200 line class solely devoted to allowing multi button command binds without having to press them at the exact same time.

posts.cooked: Do you have any video of object detection with the depth camera? I am really interested in the accuracy of it.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
I saw some teams use Choreo for straight-line trajectories. It was massive overkill for this year’s game.

Speaking of overkill, my favorite WPILib 2025 snippet is Ellipse2d.nearest() because it uses a very big hammer to solve an easy-to-describe but annoying-to-solve problem in a readable way. Here’s the C++ version we wrapped in JNI:

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
calcmogul:

I saw some teams use Choreo for straight-line trajectories. It was massive overkill for this year’s game.

Main Choreo developer here, guilty as charged lol.

On that note though, 6995 used ChoreoLib’s auto routine sequencing to create a “flex auto” where the routine was fully defined by the start position, the scoring alignment poses, and the intake position. If Choreo trajectories existed between each consecutive pair of points, the code would just string them together with proper scoring actions.

With pure PID or profiled drivetrain PID we could have done the same thing, but having Choreo for straight lines was useful for library consistency and having options to adjust individual paths.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
Ofc! We buit our backend on the Stereolabs Python SDK with intrgrated visualization tools and a flask based remote viewer, we also used CuPy to enable gpu acceleration of more directly user-space tasks like our coral orientation estimation. Everything is posted to NT and read by our robot-side API.

Our backend works for both the ZED 2 and X series but we use the ZED 2i for cost reason. Everything is user configurable through yaml configs.

The hardware side of this is pretty simple, just the camera connected via USB to our jetson, not much of intrest there. We run at 720p with NN assisted disparity estimation.

As far as the actual model we run, thats a YoloV8n model we run through the Stereolabs SDK intrgrated CUDNN-based inference framework.

Heres our jetson-side application if your curious:

GitHub - BreakerBots/ZED_FRC: ZED depth camera interface for FRC robots ZED depth camera interface for FRC robots

ZED depth camera interface for FRC robots

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked:
A custom setpoint generator for swerve that calculates feed-forward value using a simple motor model.

A path planning algorithm that plans the trajectory for the superstructure(including one that through algaes into the net)

A custom vision system running on a Jetson Orin Nano that separates processes using PyTorch multiprocessing.

A coral pose estimator that can calculate the angle of a coral using its bounding box.

A self-driving agent trained using reinforcement learning on mo simulation (didn’t get it to work yet).

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
For a basically 1 person software lead/team:

-Trying out Questnav (Offseason now) -Rewrote all code to use Akit (Offseason now) -Photovision -Maintained a swerve/vision template repos to help me support 2 other teams from around the world -Custom programmed python dashboard to run on a Samsung tablet (that acts as a second screen) for our operator to hold. It allows my operator to take instructions from drive coach, for the level and if we wanted left/right pole, or to grab algae. When I pressed my reef automation button on the driver controller, it would calculate the closest reef side and grab the current selections over network tables from the dashboard. Side note: I actually tried to run it on an old Zebra forklift terminal I had- basically an industrial iPad with windows. It ran the DS , elastic, and the dashboard. ended up lagging too much and just was not realistic.

We did custom stuff for anything we could get our hands on:

Custom Swerve

Custom Auto/Pathing Software

Custom Math functions (OK, this may have just been because we didn’t thoroughly read the docs for things like rotation around a point. )

Custom Elastic modding because we wanted sound effects for our controls based on what the robot was doing

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked: We did that too All in the name of education/prep for next year.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
This is really small for some teams but really big for our team

I was able to delegate 90% of the code to another programming mentor. And, we have another programming mentor starting soon

This allowed:

MotionMagic for all PIDs (except swerve)

properly used AdvantageKit

Helped 3 other teams with their swerve code (thanks to AdvantageKit templates)

PV with apriltag detection (got it worked and installed but never used due to camera jitter - next year we will have it fully working)

Better use of sensors than we ever had

Also personally, I’ve tried vibe coding my own personal projects. It’s very addicting and AI is an extremely powerful tool. 9/10 would recommend

Chadfrom7226:

Also personally, I’ve tried vibe coding my own personal projects. It’s very addicting and AI is an extremely powerful tool. 9/10 would recommend

This is kind of off-topic but in my experience the best use of AI such as GitHub Copilot or even just ChatGPT or Gemini is using it as a replacement for Googling. Before, when I needed to know how to do something in whatever language or framework I was writing in (I switch around a lot), I would Google it and adapt the Stack Overflow result to my code – now I just ask Copilot and it gives me an answer which is relevant to the code that’s already in place and fits into the context nicely. It’s not good at writing long chunks of code, though, in my experience.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
I had a potential field pathfinder for autos/teleop autoalign which was a modification from a impl by @Amicus1 and apparently A LOT of people copied my impl. It also won us IIC at MOSE so that was cool.

I had a fully modular auto system made that let me go to any reef location in any order, reliably. I just had to define which source to go to and which reef locations to go to, and the robot would score L4 coral there. I also had a similar system for algae autos, but we didn’t get to use it.

This was the first year we had a PhotonVision setup, and we had some suboptimal camera placements which caused issues, but it was otherwise flawless. It let us have incredibly reliable localization for the autoalign.

Personally I really liked using linear algebra for our reef alignment system. By changing the basis of the error vector (between the robot’s current position and the desired target for coral scoring) from standard (x,y) coordinates into “depth” and “lateral” coordinates (facing directly out of the AprilTag, and perpendicular to it) and running a PID controller on the depth and lateral errors, we could get the lateral movement to be faster than the depth and converge laterally first. Which means by the end of the align robot would pretty much only be moving forward.

The math isn’t that complicated but it’s great to apply some stuff we learned in math to real life!

If \theta is the angle of the AprilTag then the “depth vector” controlling forward/backward movement would be \vec D=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta \\\sin\theta \end{bmatrix} and the “lateral vector” for left/right would be \vec L=\begin{bmatrix}-\sin\theta\\\cos\theta\end{bmatrix} so \vec{L} \cdot \vec{D}=0 so they are perpendicular. Then if we have the error vector E=\begin{bmatrix}a\\b\end{bmatrix} (which we obtain with [Limelight MegaTag2 estimated pose] - [desired pose]) we would need to find d,l such that d\vec D+l\vec L=E .

Which would be: d\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta \\ \sin\theta\end{bmatrix}+l\begin{bmatrix}-\sin\theta \\ \cos\theta\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}

Which is equivalent to \begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} d \\ l \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}a \\ b \end{bmatrix} .

Multiplying by the inverse on the left gives \begin{bmatrix} d \\ l \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta\end{bmatrix}^{-1}\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} =\frac{1}{\cos^2\theta+\sin^2\theta}\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta & \sin\theta \\ -\sin\theta & \cos\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} a\cos \theta+b\sin\theta \\ -a\sin\theta+b\cos\theta \end{bmatrix} .

Then we run the PID controller on d and l individually with different K_p values.
